Halloween writer and screenwriter Debra Hill, best known for her work on the 1970s horror classic Halloween, has died in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been suffering from cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film, which starred Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it made over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide - a record for independent film at the time. Hill also worked with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog.

Born in New Jersey, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way through the ranks, becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before she began collaborating with Carpenter. She was regarded by many as a pioneering woman in film, taking on jobs in the 1970s that were more commonly taken by men.

A Russian oil company, Yukos, is facing a legal battle with the Russian government over the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. Yukos had filed for bankruptcy in the US in an attempt to use international business law to halt the forced sale of the unit, which was sold for $9.4 billion to state oil firm Rosneft. However, the sale was disrupted by the Russian authorities, who are seeking to collect a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax bill from the company. Yukos' lawyers are now claiming that the auction violated US bankruptcy law, and the company and its main shareholders are vowing to go after any company that buys its assets using all and every legal means.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64$\times$64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. Online reviews provide customers with valuable product evaluations, but these evaluations can be manipulated by professional spammers using increasingly sophisticated and insidious spamming strategies. We have developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we employ the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions follow a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. Among this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to control simultaneously the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define a measure of the robustness of an uh-fidelity transfer as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which the infidelity rises above $10^{-4}$. Our shaped pulses exhibit superior robustness to Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with an arbitrary number of components. We provide a simple evidence of the equivalence of these two constructions.

We utilize a high-order MVS scheme, enabling us to integrate with large time steps far from close encounters while maintaining the same level of accuracy as lower-order methods in the vicinity of close encounters. Our algorithm is able to resolve almost exact collisions (with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) while using the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. In reality, due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert space dimension with respect to the system size, it is very challenging to construct an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. As a comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states only needs two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

These spacetimes can break the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric, leading to a richer multipolar structure that offers a means to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. Our findings indicate that the multipole moments of these spacetimes are typically larger in absolute value than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates provide only limited constraints on fuzzballs, while future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the Lisa mission are expected to significantly improve these bounds.
